questions.text: Patient with generalized fatigue, tiredness. Primary clinical examination is uneventful. Normal TLC and DLC. No immature cells were seen. Superficial discrete lymph nodes enlarged. On biopsy showed effaced architecture, indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. CD10 and bcl2 positive.
questions.solution:
Here the question is based on immunophenotypic markers that are seen in the image below.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Burkitt's Lymphoma

  • Burkitt's lymphoma also expresses CD10, but it is BCL2 negative.
  • Burkitt's typically has a high mitotic index and a "starry sky" appearance, which is not described in this case.

Choice C: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL)

  • Follicular lymphoma is a subtype of NHL, but the question asks for a specific diagnosis.
  • Simply choosing "Non-Hodgkin's" is too broad when follicular lymphoma is clearly indicated by CD10 and BCL2 positivity.

Choice D: Mycosis Fungoides

  • Mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma) presents with skin lesions, Pautrier microabscesses, and cerebriform nuclei, none of which are described here.
  • It is not a CD10+ or BCL2+ lymphoma.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of CD10+ and BCL2+ atypical lymphoid cells with effaced lymph node architecture strongly suggests Follicular Lymphoma (t(14;18) translocation). Follicular cell lymphoma is the only lymphoma that is BCL2 positive.

questions.text: Patient with mediastinal mass was diagnosed with red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia
questions.solution:
This question is about paraneoplastic syndrome form neoplasia. Below given table is showing them all.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Bronchogenic Carcinoma

  • Lung cancer can cause paraneoplastic syndromes such as hypercalcemia (PTHrP), SIADH, Lambert-Eaton syndrome, but not red cell aplasia.

Choice B: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL)

  • NHL can cause bone marrow suppression, anemia of chronic disease, or bone marrow infiltration, but it is not classically associated with PRCA.

Choice D: Breast Cancer

  • Breast cancer is not associated with pure red cell aplasia but can cause bone marrow metastases leading to pancytopenia.

Key Takeaway:

Thymoma is the most common neoplasm associated with pure red cell aplasia, making it the correct answer.

Below the whole table is Very important for all competitive exams.

Red cell aplasia is associated with Thymic neoplasm - Thymoma.

questions.text: Pap smear with hyperchromatic nuclei pleomorphism with low maturation index involving almost all thickness. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The described Pap smear findings of hyperchromatic nuclei, pleomorphism, and low maturation index involving almost all thickness, are indicative of (Choice B) Dysplasia.

Here's a more detailed explanation:

  • Dysplasia: Refers to disordered growth of cells, which can be a precursor to cancer, it does not always progress to cancer.
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei: Nuclei that appear darker than normal due to increased DNA content.
  • Pleomorphism: Variation in the size, shape, and staining of cells, which is a sign of abnormal cell growth.
  • Low maturation index: A low proportion of mature cells compared to immature cells, indicating a disruption in the normal cell development process.
  • Involving almost all thickness: This suggests that the abnormal changes are widespread within the cervical tissue.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A): Metaplasia: A change in cell type, (replacement of one type of cell with another type) not necessarily indicative of dysplasia or cancer.
  • (Choice C): Hyperplasia: An increase in the number of cells but size remains the same. Not necessarily indicative of dysplasia or cancer.
  • (Choice D): Carcinoma: Cancer, a more advanced stage of abnormal cell growth.

Key takeaway: Hyperplasia Examples: Physiological - Pregnant uterus. Pathological - Endometrial hyperplasia. Metaplasia Examples: Physiological: In cervix during menstruation - squamous metaplasia; Pathological - Barrett's esophagus.

questions.text: A presented with c/o fatigue, weight loss, infection, has a history of benzidine exposure. He is most likely to have which CA?
questions.solution:
Here this question is about occupational exposure that is again an important topic for MCQ perspective.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Lung Cancer

  • Asbestos exposure is more strongly linked to lung cancer and mesothelioma, not benzidine.

Choice C: Blood Cancer (Leukemia)

  • Benzene exposure (not benzidine) is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and other hematologic malignancies.

Choice D: Bowel Cancer

  • Bowel cancer is linked to genetic mutations (APC, Lynch syndrome) and dietary factors (low fiber, high fat diet), not benzidine exposure.

Key Takeaway:

Benzidine - Bladder cancer.(B for B)

Asbestos - Lung Cancer

Benzene - Leukemia (Blood cancer)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with fever migratory arthritis of lower large joints, tachycardia, murmur is pansystolic. On echo mitral regurgitation is present. The biopsy shows the following?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows a collection of fibrinoid necrosis with surrounding inflammatory cells, including activated macrophages (Anitschkow cells) and multinucleated giant cells. This is characteristic of an Aschoff body, which is pathognomonic for rheumatic heart disease.

The clinical presentation of a 34-year-old woman with fever, migratory arthritis, tachycardia, pansystolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation is highly suggestive of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) leading to rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

  • (Choice A) Aschoff body (Correct Answer)
    • Found in rheumatic heart disease, particularly in myocarditis.
    • Composed of central fibrinoid necrosis, surrounding inflammatory cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells (caterpillar cells).
    • Associated with rheumatic fever, which follows Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A strep) infection.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Granuloma annulare
    • A benign skin condition presenting as dermal palisading granulomas.
    • No association with cardiac pathology or rheumatic fever.
  • (Choice C) Granulomatous vasculitis
    • Seen in conditions like Giant cell arteritis or Wegener's granulomatosis (GPA).
    • Typically affects vessels, not myocardium.
  • (Choice D) Epithelioid granuloma
    • Seen in tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, and fungal infections.
    • Composed of epithelioid histiocytes and Langhans giant cells, which are absent in the given histology.

Key takeaway:

  • The histology, clinical features, and echocardiographic finding of mitral regurgitation strongly support acute rheumatic fever (ARF) with myocarditis, confirming the presence of an Aschoff body.
  • Correct answer: (Choice A) Aschoff body.

questions.text: A software engineer presents to OPD with c/o easy fatigue. He gives a history of sitting in front of computer for 12-14 hrs per day. He takes more junk food & less fruits and veggies. CBC findings are Hb-9g%, MCV-120. What is the most likely cause of anemia due to deficiency of?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of anemia in this software engineer is Folic acid deficiency.

  • The patient presents with easy fatigue, which is a common symptom of anemia.
  • His history suggests a sedentary lifestyle with prolonged computer use and a diet deficient in fruits and vegetables, which are primary sources of folate.
  • His CBC findings:
    • Hb = 9 g% → Indicates anemia.
    • MCV = 120 fL → Macrocytosis, suggestive of megaloblastic anemia (which is caused by vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency).

Among the options, folic acid deficiency (Choice A) is the best choice, given his dietary habits and macrocytic anemia.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Iron deficiency anemia
    • Typically presents with microcytic hypochromic anemia (MCV <80 fL).
    • Not consistent with this case (MCV is 120, which is macrocytic).
  • (Choice C) Sideroblastic anemia
    • Can be microcytic, normocytic, or macrocytic.
    • Usually associated with alcoholism, lead poisoning, or genetic disorders, which are not mentioned in this case.
  • (Choice D) Acute blood loss
    • Typically causes normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100 fL)
    • No history of trauma, surgery, or significant blood loss.

Key takeaway: MCV = 120 fL → Macrocytosis, suggestive of megaloblastic anemia (which is caused by vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency).

questions.text: A patient presented with cirrhosis. On liver biopsy showed eosinophilic material cytokeratin positive. This is mostly composed of?
questions.solution:
• The patient has cirrhosis, which suggests chronic liver damage.
  • The liver biopsy shows eosinophilic material that is cytokeratin positive.
  • Cytokeratins are intermediate filaments found in epithelial cells, including hepatocytes.
  • In liver diseases, cytokeratin-positive eosinophilic inclusions are characteristic of Mallory-Denk bodies (MDBs), which are composed of intermediate filaments.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Actin →
    • Actin is part of the microfilament system, mainly involved in cell motility and cytoskeletal structure, but it is not the primary component of cytokeratin-positive inclusions.
  • (Choice B) Microtubule →
    • Microtubules are composed of tubulin and are involved in intracellular transport and mitosis, not cytokeratin-positive inclusions.
  • (Choice D) Fibronectin →
    • Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein, not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies or cytokeratin inclusions.

Key takeaway:

The eosinophilic cytokeratin-positive material in cirrhosis is mainly composed of intermediate filaments (cytokeratins)

questions.text: 50-year-old male c/o fatigability persistent for one year. Mild anemia massive splenomegaly. Hb 10gm%, TLC 120000, platelet 500000, neutrophils 60, basophil 4, eosinophil 6, lymphocyte 15, myeloblast 3. Rest were myelocyte and bands. M:E ratio of 18:1. Most specific further investigation
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation strongly suggests Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) based on the following findings:

  1. Clinical Features:
    • Fatigability for one year (suggests a chronic condition).
    • Massive splenomegaly (common in CML).
  2. Hematological Findings:
    • Mild anemia (Hb 10 g%)
    • Marked leukocytosis (TLC 120,000/µL)
    • Thrombocytosis (Platelet count 500,000/µL)
    • Differential count:
      • Neutrophils 60%, Basophils 4%, Eosinophils 6% (increased basophils & eosinophils suggest CML).
      • Myeloblasts 3%, Myelocytes, and Bands present (indicating a left shift).
    • Myeloid: Erythroid (M:E) ratio of 18:1 (favoring a myeloproliferative disorder, particularly CML).

Most Specific Further Investigation:

  • Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) and Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for BCR-ABL1 fusion gene
    • Confirms the Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22) translocation, the hallmark of CML.
    • PCR is the most sensitive test to detect minimal residual disease and monitor response to therapy.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Immunophenotyping
    • Useful for acute leukemias (e.g., Acute Myeloid Leukemia or Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia).
    • CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN), best diagnosed with genetic testing, not flow cytometry.
  • (Choice C) Whole-body PET-CT
    • Used in lymphomas and solid tumors, not for diagnosing CML.
  • (Choice D) Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase (LAP) Score
    • Low LAP score is characteristic of CML, but it is not specific or confirmatory.
    • FISH/PCR for BCR-ABL is the gold standard.

Key takeaway: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) and Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for BCR-ABL1 fusion gene Confirms the Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22) translocation, the hallmark of CML.

questions.text: Familial HNPCC has a defect in?
questions.solution:
Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch Syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes. These mutations lead to microsatellite instability (MSI), a hallmark of HNPCC-related cancers.

Key Genetic Defect:

  • The DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes involved in HNPCC include:
    • MLH1
    • MSH2
    • MSH6
    • PMS2
    • EPCAM (indirectly affects MSH2 expression)
  • Function of MMR Genes:
    • These genes help in detecting and correcting base mismatches during DNA replication.
    • When defective, they cause accumulation of errors in microsatellites, leading to microsatellite instability (MSI-H) and an increased risk of colorectal, endometrial, gastric, and other cancers.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Nucleotide excision repair (NER)
    • This pathway repairs bulky DNA adducts (e.g., UV-induced pyrimidine dimers).
    • Defective in Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP), not HNPCC.
  • (Choice B) Base excision repair (BER)
    • Repairs small, non-bulky base lesions (e.g., deaminated bases, alkylated bases).
    • Defective in MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP), not HNPCC.
  • (Choice C) Point mutations
    • Point mutations occur in many genetic disorders but are not the primary defect in HNPCC.
    • HNPCC is specifically associated with MMR gene mutations and microsatellite instability, not just simple point mutations.

Key takeaway:

HNPCC (Lynch Syndrome) is caused by defects in the mismatch repair (MMR) genesr.

questions.text: Poor prognostic marker for multiple myeloma is?
questions.solution:
Multiple Myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell malignancy, and prognosis is determined by biochemical and cytogenetic markers.

Why is Beta 2-Microglobulin a Poor Prognostic Marker?

  • Beta 2-microglobulin (B2M) is a small protein released by all nucleated cells, including malignant plasma cells.
  • In Multiple Myeloma, B2M levels correlate with tumor burden and renal dysfunction.
  • Higher levels of B2M indicate poor prognosis due to:
    • Higher tumor load.
    • Increased renal impairment.
    • More aggressive disease progression.
  • International Staging System (ISS) for Multiple Myeloma includes B2M levels as a critical prognostic marker.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Serum Creatinine
    • Elevated creatinine indicates renal dysfunction, common in MM, but it is not a primary prognostic marker.
    • Renal failure worsens prognosis, but B2M is more directly correlated with disease severity.
  • (Choice C) Calcium
    • Hypercalcemia occurs due to bone lysis, but it is a complication, not a reliable independent prognostic factor.
  • (Choice D) Protein
    • Monoclonal protein (M-spike) levels help in diagnosis and monitoring response to treatment but are not as prognostically significant as B2M.

Key takeaway:

Beta 2-microglobulin (B2M) is the most significant poor prognostic marker in Multiple Myeloma.

questions.text: 20 year old boy present with gum bleeding and easy bruisability. Fever for one month HB 3gm/dl, platelet 10,000/ul, ANC 150/ul. Non specific general examination finding except for significant pallor and petechial rash all over the body. Ps: macrocytes corrected retic 0.5% Bone marrow fatty, absent megakaryocyte, no immature cells.
questions.solution:
History of Pancytopenia. ANC < 500. Retic < 1% all fulfilling the Criteria of Aplastic Anemia.

Other options do not show Pancytopenia.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Disseminated TB Involving Bone Marrow

  • Disseminated tuberculosis can involve the bone marrow and cause pancytopenia, but it typically shows caseating granulomas in the marrow, which are absent here.
  • The fatty marrow without granulomas argues against TB.

Choice C: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

  • PNH presents with hemolytic anemia, hemoglobinuria, and thrombosis, which are not seen here.
  • Bone marrow in PNH may show hypocellularity, but flow cytometry (CD55/CD59 deficiency) is needed for diagnosis.

Choice D: Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

  • MDS presents with pancytopenia but also has dysplastic changes and increased blasts, which are absent in this case.
  • Bone marrow in MDS is usually hypercellular or normocellular, not fatty and hypocellular.

Key Takeaway: Aplastic Anemia is diagnosis of exclusion in case of Pancytopenia. For diagnosis of it above mentioned criteria should be fulfilled.

questions.text: Tocilizumab is a newer monoclonal antibody for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It acts against
questions.solution:
Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptors. IL-6 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by promoting inflammation and joint destruction.

Incorrect Choices explanation:

(Choice A) IL-3 → Involved in hematopoiesis, not a major target in RA.

(Choice B) IL-12 → Mainly involved in Th1 immune response and not directly implicated in RA treatment.

(Choice D) IL-2 → Plays a role in T-cell activation, targeted in other immune disorders but not in RA.

Key takeaway:

Tocilizumab blocks the IL-6 receptor (IL-6R), thereby inhibiting the downstream inflammatory signaling.

This leads to a reduction in joint inflammation, pain, and progressive joint damage seen in RA.

It is particularly used in patients with inadequate response to TNF inhibitors.

Clinical Uses:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA)

Cytokine release syndrome (CRS) associated with CAR-T cell therapy

questions.text: All are increased in IDA except?
questions.solution:
Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by decreased iron stores and impaired hemoglobin synthesis. Let's analyze the given options:

What Increases in IDA?

  • (Choice A) Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) ↑
    • TIBC represents the ability of transferrin to bind iron.
    • In IDA, iron levels are low, so the liver increases transferrin production to capture more iron, leading to increased TIBC.
  • (Choice B) Soluble Transferrin Receptor (sTfR) ↑
    • In IDA, cells upregulate transferrin receptors to absorb more iron from circulation.
    • Hence, soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR) is increased in IDA but normal in anemia of chronic disease (ACD).
  • (Choice D) Iron Protoporphyrin ↑
    • Iron protoporphyrin is a precursor of heme synthesis.
    • In IDA, iron is deficient, so free protoporphyrin accumulates (increased iron-free protoporphyrin).

What Decreases in IDA?

  • (Choice C) Transferrin Saturation ↓ (Correct Answer)
    • Transferrin saturation = (Serum Iron / TIBC) × 100
    • In IDA:
      • Serum iron is low
      • TIBC is high
      • So, transferrin saturation is LOW (<16%).

Key takeaway:

Transferrin saturation (C) is decreased in IDA.

questions.text: 35 year old female presents with weak pulses in upper limbs, BP 90/60 mm Hg, retinal haemorrhages +nt. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches, leading to narrowing (stenosis), occlusion, or aneurysm formation.

Key Features in the Question:

  1. Weak Pulses in Upper Limbs → Suggests subclavian artery involvement, which is a hallmark of Takayasu arteritis.
  2. Low Blood Pressure (90/60 mm Hg) → Due to vascular stenosis and ischemia.
  3. Retinal Hemorrhages → Due to ocular ischemia caused by reduced blood supply to the retinal arteries.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
    • Affects medium-sized arteries, but spares the lungs.
    • Presents with systemic vasculitis symptoms (renal involvement, skin nodules, neuropathy, GI symptoms), but does not cause pulselessness.
    • No granulomas in histology.
  • (Choice B) Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA)
    • Small-vessel vasculitis, associated with p-ANCA.
    • Features include rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), pulmonary involvement (hemoptysis), and palpable purpura.
    • No large vessel involvement or pulselessness.
  • (Choice D) Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP)
    • IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis, mainly affecting children.
    • Features palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis, not large vessel disease.
    • Does not cause pulselessness or retinal hemorrhages.

Key takeaway:

This patient's pulseless upper limb, low BP, and retinal hemorrhages strongly suggest Takayasu arteritis.

questions.text: H/o male child presenting with Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes, his eye examination shows white reflex given. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes along with white reflex (leukocoria) strongly suggests retinoblastoma, the most common malignant intraocular tumor in children.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A: Medulloblastoma

  • Medulloblastoma is a cerebellar tumor and does not cause leukocoria.
  • Homer-Wright rosettes, not Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, are seen in medulloblastoma.

Choice C: Rhabdomyosarcoma

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma can affect the orbit, but it does not produce leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
  • Presents with a rapidly growing orbital mass, not a white reflex.

Choice D: Coat's Disease

  • Coat's disease is a non-malignant retinal disorder that can also cause leukocoria, mimicking retinoblastoma.
  • It involves abnormal retinal vessels with exudative retinal detachment but lacks Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

Key takeaway:

Leukocoria (White Reflex in the Eye) → Due to tumor mass in the retina.

Strabismus (Misalignment of the Eyes) → Due to retinal involvement affecting vision.

Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes → Histopathological hallmark of retinoblastoma, showing tumor cells arranged in a circular pattern with a central lumen.

Mutation in the RB1 Gene on Chromosome 13 → Inactivates the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor gene.

questions.text: 10 year male child with generalised edema. Cholesterol 238 mg/dl. Urine protein 3+, stool microscopy was done which shows fat in stools.
questions.solution:
The given case describes a 10-year-old male with the following features:

  1. Generalized edema → Suggests significant protein loss leading to hypoalbuminemia and fluid retention.
  2. Cholesterol = 238 mg/dL → Hyperlipidemia, a characteristic feature of nephrotic syndrome.
  3. Urine protein 3+ → Suggests massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), a diagnostic criterion for nephrotic syndrome.
  4. Fat in stool (Steatorrhea) → Seen in protein-losing enteropathy, often secondary to nephrotic syndrome.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  1. (Choice A) Goodpasture's Syndrome
    • Typically presents with hemoptysis + hematuria due to anti-GBM antibodies.
    • Not associated with massive proteinuria or hyperlipidemia.
  2. (Choice B) Urine Infection (UTI)
    • Would present with dysuria, fever, pyuria, and bacteriuria.
    • Does not cause generalized edema or nephrotic-range proteinuria.
  3. (Choice D) Nephritic Syndrome
    • Features hematuria (cola-colored urine), hypertension, oliguria, and mild proteinuria.
    • This patient has massive proteinuria, hyperlipidemia, and edema, favoring nephrotic over nephritic syndrome.

Key takeaway:

Nephrotic Syndrome Key Features (Mnemonic: PALE)

  • Proteinuria (>3.5 g/day, dipstick 3+ or more).
  • Albumin low (Hypoalbuminemia <3.0 g/dL).
  • Lipid levels elevated (Hyperlipidemia).
  • Edema (Generalized, periorbital, and dependent).

questions.text: A patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung has undergone pulmonectomy. During the procedure blackish hilar lymph nodes of 1 cm are seen. Identify the cause of pigmentation.
questions.solution:
The presence of blackish hilar lymph nodes in a patient with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung suggests anthracotic pigmentation.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Hemosiderosis
    • Caused by iron deposition due to chronic hemorrhage or hemolysis.
    • Appears golden-brown, not black.
    • Seen in chronic pulmonary congestion (e.g., left heart failure), but not a primary finding in lung cancer.
  • (Choice C) Lipofuscin
    • "Wear and tear" pigment, appearing yellow-brown, not black.
    • Commonly seen in aging cells, liver, and heart.
  • (Choice D) Melanin
    • Found in melanocytes, typically in melanomas.
    • Not found in lymph nodes related to lung cancer.

Key takeaway:

Why Anthracotic Pigmentation?

  • Anthracosis is due to the accumulation of carbon-laden macrophages (dust cells) in the lungs and hilar lymph nodes.
  • Common in:
    • Smokers
    • Urban dwellers exposed to pollution
    • Coal workers (Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis)
  • The pigment appears black under the microscope.
